title: Succession: bankers await the heir to the Murdoch throne
text:
Two big things to start: first, the future of Greensill Capital, the finance group advised by the former UK prime minister David Cameron, is hanging in the balance after Credit Suisse froze $10bn of funds linked to the firm. Read more here.

Next up: the board of directors of Danone has sought to calm an acrimonious public fight with activist shareholders by agreeing to split the chairman and chief executive roles now both held by Emmanuel Faber. See more here.

Rupert Murdoch's 90th year and the big succession question

To be a fly on the wall at Rupert Murdoch's 90th birthday party later this month.

If it were depicted in the fictional HBO series Succession, the tale of an ageing media magnate's dysfunctional family loosely inspired by the Australian tycoon's legacy, the fête would surely involve hyperdecanted wine, hurling insults, and some legendary raps.

However, the real-life family media empire has garnered an audience of its own — dealmakers included — as the fate of the Murdoch family trust, which holds shares in News Corp and Fox Corporation, takes centre stage.

Most billionaires Murdoch's age opt to spend their twilight years sipping Scotch and golfing in the Palm Beach breeze. But the soon-to-be nonagenarian has been busy turning Fox News Channel into a controversial conservative powerhouse, making advantageous friends in the White House (albeit there was probably quite a lot of golfing there), making $71bn from Disney for most of 21st Century Fox, and, most recently, closing a global content deal with Google. 

But it's the deals Murdoch didn't make that will define his empire's next chapter. The family patriarch held on to a collection of his “favourite toys” after the Disney sale — Fox News, newspapers including The Sun and the New York Post, and other television networks. 

The 2019 deal forbade any further sales for a two-year period, a restriction that was lifted last month. That means — assuming Murdoch isn't actually immortal — his inner circle is preparing for a flurry of dealmaking to hand off his legacy.

Lachlan Murdoch, the eldest son, is heir apparent to it all. But the succession question still looms ahead. 

The trust acts as one in company matters, wielding roughly 40 per cent of voting B shares. Once the next generation takes over, however, the power to determine the trust's position is dispersed equally between Murdoch's four eldest children, while his youngest two daughters are beneficiaries.

None of the children have the votes to exert control alone, and clashing views between the siblings could stand in the way of reaching any easy consensus. 

There are three potential scenarios for how it could all play out, depending on how much control Lachlan wishes to retain over his father's legacy, according to insiders:

  1. Selling Fox — it's an option sources close to Murdoch say he could be obliged to, if it's in his family's best interest. But there may not be a long line of bidders. “You're unlikely to see any well-known private equity group like Blackstone or KKR taking over. The reputational risk is huge,” one executive said. 

  2. Reuniting parts of Fox with News Corp, which owns The Wall Street Journal and other publications, and handing over the reins to News Corp chief and longtime Murdoch confidant Robert Thomson.

  3. Placing Lachlan in charge and letting things carry on the way they are. The move would still require some reshuffling assets, but is in many ways the preferred option, said people close to Murdoch.

Go deeper with this big read on what's next for the Murdoch empire by the FT's Alex Barker and Anna Nicolaou, and DD's James Fontanella-Khan.

Dealmakers spin the Spac wheel of fortune

If anyone needed further proof that blank-cheque companies have become a staple of Wall Street, they need only look at the level of dealmaking in February. 

Special purpose acquisition companies, or Spacs, struck $109bn worth of deals globally last month alone, according to Refinitiv data. 

There are some familiar names that have contributed heavily to the deal total, such as the electric car maker Lucid, which agreed to go public via a merger with Churchill Capital IV at a $24bn valuation — the largest deal to date for Spacs. 

Others include Joby Aviation, the electric flying taxi developer, that announced a deal with a Spac set up by Reid Hoffman and Mark Pincus, respectively the co-founders of LinkedIn and Zynga. Its rival Archer will also go public in a transaction with a blank-cheque company backed by the investment banker Ken Moelis.

What do these companies have in common? Aside from all developing electric modes of transport, they also have no revenues to speak of. This is the Spac trend we've been telling you about.

Revenues, and at times even proof of concept, isn't that important to Spac deals because unlike traditional listings, companies that go public via a blank-cheque vehicle are allowed to show projections. Some seem reasonable while others veer into the ridiculous but the idea is to sell the dream — like imminent space travel, for one.

Several dealmakers have described investing in these start-ups as taking the “spray and pray” approach. Invest in as many companies as possible and one will, hopefully, turn out to be the next Google or Amazon. 

The frenzied dealmaking and rapid fundraising — 188 vehicles have raised $58bn so far this year, marking a significant acceleration from 2020 when 244 Spacs raised $78bn across the year as a whole — is doing nothing to assuage fears that a bubble has formed. Especially at these valuations. 

Novavax: vaccinated ever-after

Third time's the charm, they say. What about the 33rd time?

That's how many years it took Novavax, after pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into research and development for vaccines without a single approved shot, to near its first success story. 

The pharmaceuticals company was facing a delisting from the Nasdaq exchange just a year before the pandemic struck, with short interest hitting 30 per cent as of January last year. 

Shortseller Citron Research reportedly dismissed them as a “serial promise and non-deliver[er]” in a deleted tweet.

Novavax chief Stanley Erck isn't losing any sleep over the short-seller's soiled bets. “The shorts are not my friends, ever. I love to disappoint the shorts,” he told the FT's Hannah Kuchler.

Now, its Covid vaccine is swiftly approaching approval in the UK, with the US next on its radar. 

“It's a Cinderella story,” said Stacey Schultz-Cherry, an infectious disease specialist at St Jude Children's Research Hospital in Tennessee, of the small company's ability to compete with more established players.

For everyone except the short-sellers, that is.

Job moves

  • Mark Machin, the head of Canada's largest pension fund, has resigned after he travelled to the United Arab Emirates and received the Covid-19 vaccine. The country has seen an influx of wealthy individuals hoping to take advantage of an emerging grey market in vaccines. Read more here.

  • ExxonMobil is appointing Altarios chief executive Michael Angelakis and the activist investor Jeffrey Ubben as directors to its board, the latest move to placate activist shareholders pushing for a strategic overhaul at the US oil company.

  • The head of Goldman Sachs' consumer finance division, Omer Ismail, and one of its top executives, David Stark, are both leaving to join a fintech start-up backed by Walmart and Ribbit Capital.

  • Additionally, Eric Lane, the co-head of Goldman's asset-management arm, is leaving to join Chase Coleman's Tiger Global Management.

  • Jan du Plessis will retire as BT's chairman after less than four years in the role.

  • The law firm Latham & Watkins has hired former Federal Trade Commission bureau director and ex-Kirkland & Ellis partner Ian Conner, marking the latest departure of a government lawyer in the wake of the US election.
